concepts.title: Orders vs Spots vs Logs
concepts.description: Understanding the relationship between orders, spots, and logs
concepts.content:
# Orders vs Spots vs Logs

## Orders

An **Order** is a contract for advertising that specifies:
- How many commercials to run (total spots)
- When they should run (date range)
- What type of scheduling (ROS, Daypart, Fixed Time)
- How much it costs

Think of an order as the "contract" or "agreement."

## Spots

A **Spot** is a single commercial placement at a specific date and time.

- One order can have many spots
- Each spot has a scheduled date and time
- Spots are created from orders by the traffic manager
- Spots can be SCHEDULED, AIRED, MISSED, or CANCELLED

Think of spots as the individual "appointments" for commercials.

## Logs

A **Daily Log** is the complete programming schedule for a day.

- Contains all spots scheduled for that day
- Also includes music, IDs, news, and other programming
- Generated by the log generator
- Published to the automation system (LibreTime)

Think of a log as the "playlist" or "schedule" for the entire day.

## Relationship

1. **Sales Person** creates an **Order** (contract for 100 spots)
2. **Traffic Manager** creates 100 **Spots** from that order (scheduled at specific times)
3. **Log Generator** includes those spots in **Daily Logs** (one log per day)
4. Spots air according to the log schedule

## Example

- **Order**: "ABC Restaurant - 100 spots, Jan 1-31, ROS, 30 seconds"
- **Spots**: 100 individual spots scheduled throughout January
- **Logs**: 31 daily logs (one for each day in January), each containing the spots scheduled for that day

concepts.title: Rate Types Explained
concepts.description: Understanding ROS, Daypart, and Fixed Time rate types
concepts.content:
# Rate Types Explained

## ROS (Run of Schedule)

**What it means**: Your commercial can play at any time during the day, whenever there's an available spot.

**Best for**:
- Advertisers who want maximum flexibility
- Budget-conscious advertisers
- Filling inventory

**Pricing**: Usually the lowest rate because the station has flexibility in scheduling.

**Example**: "Run my 30-second spot 50 times in January, any time of day."

## Daypart

**What it means**: Your commercial plays during specific time periods (dayparts).

**Common Dayparts**:
- **Morning Drive**: 6:00 AM - 10:00 AM (highest audience)
- **Midday**: 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM
- **Afternoon Drive**: 3:00 PM - 7:00 PM (high audience)
- **Evening**: 7:00 PM - Midnight
- **Overnight**: Midnight - 6:00 AM

**Best for**:
- Targeting specific audiences
- Advertisers who want prime time placement
- Businesses with time-sensitive messages

**Pricing**: Higher than ROS, varies by daypart (Morning and Afternoon Drive are most expensive).

**Example**: "Run my 30-second spot 50 times in January during Morning Drive only."

## Fixed Time

**What it means**: Your commercial plays at exact, specified times.

**Best for**:
- Advertisers who need specific times (e.g., lunch specials at noon)
- Time-sensitive promotions
- Advertisers who want consistency

**Pricing**: Usually the highest rate because it's the most restrictive.

**Example**: "Run my 30-second spot every day at 8:00 AM and 5:00 PM in January."

## Choosing a Rate Type

- **Budget-focused**: Choose ROS
- **Audience-targeted**: Choose Daypart
- **Time-specific**: Choose Fixed Time

concepts.title: Dayparts and Break Positions
concepts.description: Understanding dayparts and break position assignments
concepts.content:
# Dayparts and Break Positions

## Dayparts

Dayparts divide the broadcast day into time periods, each with different:
- Audience sizes
- Demographics
- Rates

### Standard Dayparts

- **Morning Drive** (6:00 AM - 10:00 AM)
  - Largest audience
  - Commuters
  - Highest rates

- **Midday** (10:00 AM - 3:00 PM)
  - Moderate audience
  - At-work listeners
  - Moderate rates

- **Afternoon Drive** (3:00 PM - 7:00 PM)
  - Large audience
  - Commuters
  - High rates

- **Evening** (7:00 PM - Midnight)
  - Smaller audience
  - At-home listeners
  - Lower rates

- **Overnight** (Midnight - 6:00 AM)
  - Smallest audience
  - Night workers, insomniacs
  - Lowest rates

## Break Positions

Break positions indicate where in a commercial break your spot plays.

### Position Labels

- **A Position**: First spot in the break
- **B Position**: Second spot in the break
- **C Position**: Third spot in the break
- And so on...

### Why Position Matters

- **A Position**: Listeners are most likely to hear it (highest retention)
- **Later Positions**: Some listeners may tune out
- **Premium Pricing**: A-position spots cost more

### Break Structure

A typical break might look like:
- 8:00:00 - Station ID (15 seconds)
- 8:00:15 - **A Position** - Premium Advertiser (30 seconds)
- 8:00:45 - **B Position** - Regular Advertiser (30 seconds)
- 8:01:15 - **C Position** - PSA (30 seconds)
- 8:01:45 - Music resumes

## Assigning Positions

Traffic managers assign positions based on:
- Order requirements
- Rate structure
- Advertiser preferences
- Contract terms

concepts.title: Clock Templates
concepts.description: Understanding clock templates and how they structure programming
concepts.content:
# Clock Templates

## What is a Clock Template?

A clock template is a blueprint for how each hour of radio programming is structured.

Think of it like a recipe that says:
- At 0:00 (top of hour): Station ID
- At 0:15: Music
- At 0:45: Commercial break (3 spots)
- At 1:30: Music
- At 2:00: News
- And so on...

## Elements in a Clock

Clock templates define different types of content:

- **MUS**: Music tracks
- **ADV**: Commercial advertisements
- **PSA**: Public service announcements
- **IDS**: Station identification
- **NEW**: News segments
- **LIN**: Liners (short station promos)
- **INT**: Interviews
- **PRO**: Promos
- **BED**: Music beds (background music)

## How Clocks Work

1. **Template Creation**: Program director creates clock templates
2. **Log Generation**: Log generator uses templates to create daily logs
3. **Element Selection**: System selects appropriate content for each element:
   - Music from library
   - Scheduled spots for ADV slots
   - Appropriate IDs, news, etc.
4. **Timing**: Everything is precisely timed

## Example Clock Structure

**Hour 1 (6:00 AM - 7:00 AM)**:
- 6:00:00 - Station ID (30 seconds)
- 6:00:30 - Music (3:30)
- 6:04:00 - Commercial Break (3 spots, 2:00)
- 6:06:00 - Music (4:00)
- 6:10:00 - News (2:00)
- 6:12:00 - Music (3:00)
- 6:15:00 - Commercial Break (2 spots, 1:30)
- ...continues for full hour

## Multiple Clocks

Stations typically have different clocks for:
- Different days of the week
- Different times of day
- Special programming

Example:
- Weekday Morning Clock (6 AM - 10 AM)
- Weekday Midday Clock (10 AM - 3 PM)
- Weekend Clock
- Holiday Clock

## Creating Logs

When generating a daily log:
1. System selects appropriate clock template for each hour
2. Fills in scheduled spots
3. Selects music from library
4. Places IDs, news, and other elements
5. Creates complete hour-by-hour schedule

concepts.title: Campaign Management
concepts.description: How campaigns organize related advertising
concepts.content:
# Campaign Management

## What is a Campaign?

A campaign groups related advertising spots under a unified marketing initiative.

**Example**: A restaurant might have a campaign called "Summer Specials" that includes:
- Breakfast special ad
- Lunch special ad
- Dinner special ad
- All running during summer months

## Campaign Benefits

- **Organization**: Group related ads together
- **Tracking**: See performance of related advertising
- **Rotation**: Manage multiple copy versions
- **Reporting**: Analyze campaign effectiveness

## Campaign Components

- **Multiple Orders**: A campaign can span multiple orders
- **Multiple Copy Versions**: Different ads within same campaign
- **Rotation Rules**: How different versions rotate
- **Date Range**: When campaign runs

## Creating a Campaign

1. Navigate to campaign management
2. Create new campaign
3. Name the campaign
4. Set date range
5. Add orders to campaign
6. Upload copy versions
7. Set rotation rules

## Campaign vs Order

- **Order**: Contract for specific number of spots
- **Campaign**: Marketing initiative that may include multiple orders

**Example**:
- Campaign: "Holiday Sale 2024"
  - Order 1: 50 spots in December (general sale)
  - Order 2: 30 spots Dec 15-24 (last minute deals)
  - Order 3: 20 spots Dec 26-31 (after-Christmas sale)

concepts.title: Copy Management
concepts.description: Managing commercial audio files and scripts
concepts.content:
# Copy Management

## What is Copy?

Copy is the actual commercial creative - either:
- **Pre-produced audio file**: Recorded commercial ready to play
- **Script**: Text for live read by DJ/host

## Copy Lifecycle

1. **Upload**: Sales person or advertiser uploads copy
2. **Assignment**: Copy assigned to order or campaign
3. **Versioning**: Multiple versions for A/B testing
4. **Expiration**: Copy expires after campaign ends
5. **Archival**: Old copy archived for records

## Types of Copy

### Pre-Produced Audio
- Recorded commercial
- Uploaded as audio file (MP3, WAV, etc.)
- Plays automatically
- No talent needed

### Live Read Script
- Text script
- DJ/host reads on-air
- More personal
- Requires coordination

### Multi-Cut
- Multiple versions of same commercial
- Rotates automatically
- Prevents listener fatigue

## Copy Requirements

- **Format**: MP3, WAV, or other audio format
- **Length**: Must match spot length (15, 30, or 60 seconds)
- **Quality**: Broadcast quality
- **Content**: Must comply with station policies

## Copy Instructions

For live reads, include:
- Tone (serious, fun, etc.)
- Emphasis points
- Special pronunciation
- Timing

## Best Practices

- Upload copy as soon as order is created
- Verify audio quality before upload
- Set expiration dates
- Keep multiple versions for rotation
- Archive old copy for records

concepts.title: Makegoods
concepts.description: Understanding makegoods and when they're needed
concepts.content:
# Makegoods

## What is a Makegood?

A makegood is a free replacement spot given when a scheduled commercial doesn't air as planned.

## When Makegoods Are Needed

- **Technical Issues**: Equipment failure, power outage
- **Programming Changes**: Breaking news, special programming
- **Station Error**: Mistake in scheduling or playback
- **Preemption**: Higher priority content replaces scheduled spot

## Makegood Process

1. **Identify Missed Spot**: System or traffic manager identifies spot that didn't air
2. **Create Makegood**: Traffic manager creates makegood record
3. **Schedule Replacement**: New spot scheduled at no charge
4. **Track**: Makegood tracked for contract fulfillment
5. **Invoice**: Makegood appears on invoice with $0 amount (for record keeping)

## Makegood Requirements

- **Comparable Placement**: Should be in similar daypart/time
- **Same Length**: Must match original spot length
- **Timely**: Scheduled as soon as possible
- **Free**: No charge to advertiser

## Makegood vs Credit

- **Makegood**: Free replacement spot
- **Credit**: Money back on invoice

Makegoods are preferred because:
- Maintains contract fulfillment
- Keeps advertising running
- Better for advertiser (they get the spot)

## Best Practices

- Create makegoods promptly
- Communicate with advertiser
- Schedule in comparable time periods
- Document reason for makegood
- Track all makegoods for reporting

concepts.title: Daypart Management
concepts.description: How to create and manage dayparts for scheduling and pricing
concepts.content:
# Daypart Management

## What is Daypart Management?

Daypart Management is where you define the time periods used for scheduling commercials and setting different rates. Dayparts divide the broadcast day into segments, each with different audience sizes and pricing.

## Why Use Dayparts?

- **Pricing**: Different time periods have different rates (Morning Drive costs more than Overnight)
- **Scheduling**: Traffic managers know when to schedule spots for daypart-specific orders
- **Targeting**: Advertisers can target specific audiences (commuters, at-work, at-home)
- **Organization**: Helps organize inventory and availability

## Standard Dayparts

Most stations use these standard dayparts:

- **Morning Drive**: 6:00 AM - 10:00 AM
  - Highest audience (commuters)
  - Highest rates
  - Prime advertising time

- **Midday**: 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM
  - Moderate audience
  - Moderate rates
  - At-work listeners

- **Afternoon Drive**: 3:00 PM - 7:00 PM
  - High audience (commuters)
  - High rates
  - Second prime time

- **Evening**: 7:00 PM - Midnight
  - Smaller audience
  - Lower rates
  - At-home listeners

- **Overnight**: Midnight - 6:00 AM
  - Smallest audience
  - Lowest rates
  - Night workers, insomniacs

## Creating a Daypart

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Dayparts**
2. Click **Add Daypart**
3. Enter daypart details:
   - **Name**: Descriptive name (e.g., "Morning Drive", "Prime Time")
   - **Start Time**: When the daypart begins (e.g., 06:00)
   - **End Time**: When the daypart ends (e.g., 10:00)
   - **Category**: Optional - group related dayparts (e.g., "Prime Time", "Off-Peak")
   - **Description**: Optional notes about the daypart
   - **Active**: Check to enable, uncheck to disable
4. Click **Save**

## Daypart Categories

Categories help organize dayparts into groups:

- **Prime Time**: High-value dayparts (Morning Drive, Afternoon Drive)
- **Off-Peak**: Lower-value dayparts (Evening, Overnight)
- **Custom**: Your own groupings

### Creating a Daypart Category

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Daypart Categories**
2. Click **Add Category**
3. Enter category name and description
4. Optionally set color and icon for visual organization
5. Click **Save**

## Using Dayparts

### In Orders

When creating an order with **Daypart** rate type:
1. Select rate type: **Daypart**
2. Traffic manager will schedule spots only within the specified daypart times
3. Pricing reflects the daypart rate structure

### In Scheduling

Traffic managers use dayparts to:
- Know when spots can be scheduled
- Ensure spots air during correct time periods
- Manage inventory by daypart
- Set appropriate pricing

## Best Practices

- **Standard Times**: Use industry-standard daypart times for consistency
- **Clear Names**: Use descriptive names ("Morning Drive" not "AM1")
- **Categories**: Group related dayparts for easier management
- **Active/Inactive**: Disable dayparts you're not currently using
- **Documentation**: Add descriptions explaining special dayparts
- **Consistency**: Keep daypart times consistent across the system

## Daypart vs Rate Type

- **Daypart (Rate Type)**: An order that requires spots to be scheduled within specific daypart times
- **Daypart (Time Period)**: The actual time period definition (created in Daypart Management)

**Example**:
- Create a daypart called "Morning Drive" (6am-10am) in Daypart Management
- Create an order with rate type "Daypart"
- Traffic manager schedules spots only during Morning Drive hours

concepts.title: Daypart Categories
concepts.description: Organizing dayparts into groups for better management
concepts.content:
# Daypart Categories

## What are Daypart Categories?

Daypart Categories are groups that organize related dayparts together. They help you:
- Organize dayparts visually
- Group similar dayparts (e.g., all "Prime Time" dayparts)
- Filter and manage dayparts more easily
- Apply consistent settings to groups of dayparts

## Common Category Examples

- **Prime Time**: High-value dayparts (Morning Drive, Afternoon Drive)
- **Off-Peak**: Lower-value dayparts (Evening, Overnight, Midday)
- **Drive Time**: Commuter-focused dayparts
- **Weekend**: Special weekend dayparts
- **Holiday**: Holiday-specific programming

## Creating Categories

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Daypart Categories**
2. Click **Add Category**
3. Enter:
   - **Name**: Category name (e.g., "Prime Time")
   - **Description**: What dayparts belong in this category
   - **Color**: Optional hex color for visual organization
   - **Icon**: Optional icon name
   - **Sort Order**: Number to control display order
   - **Active**: Enable or disable
4. Click **Save**

## Assigning Dayparts to Categories

When creating or editing a daypart:
1. Select a category from the dropdown
2. Daypart is now grouped with others in that category
3. You can filter dayparts by category

## Benefits

- **Organization**: See related dayparts together
- **Filtering**: Filter dayparts by category
- **Reporting**: Generate reports by category
- **Visual**: Color coding helps identify categories quickly

## Best Practices

- Use clear, descriptive category names
- Group dayparts logically
- Keep categories active/inactive as needed
- Use colors and icons for visual organization
- Set sort order for consistent display

concepts.title: Rotation Rules
concepts.description: How rotation rules control spot and copy rotation
concepts.content:
# Rotation Rules

## What are Rotation Rules?

Rotation Rules control how spots and copy versions rotate throughout the day. They ensure:
- Spots don't play too close together
- Multiple copy versions rotate evenly
- Spots are distributed across dayparts
- Campaigns maintain proper spacing

## When to Use Rotation Rules

- **Multiple Copy Versions**: When you have several versions of the same commercial
- **Campaign Management**: To control how campaign spots rotate
- **Daypart Distribution**: To ensure spots are spread across different dayparts
- **Separation Requirements**: To prevent spots from playing too close together

## Types of Rotation

### Sequential
- Spots play in order (Version 1, then Version 2, then Version 3, repeat)
- Predictable rotation
- Good for campaigns with clear sequence

### Random
- Spots play in random order
- Less predictable
- Prevents listener fatigue

### Weighted
- Some versions play more often than others
- Based on weights you assign
- Good for A/B testing

## Creating Rotation Rules

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Rotation Rules**
2. Click **Add Rotation Rule**
3. Enter rule details:
   - **Name**: Descriptive name
   - **Rotation Type**: Sequential, Random, or Weighted
   - **Daypart**: Optional - apply only to specific daypart
   - **Campaign**: Optional - apply to specific campaign
   - **Min Separation**: Minimum minutes between spots
   - **Max Per Hour**: Maximum spots per hour
   - **Max Per Day**: Maximum spots per day
   - **Weights**: For weighted rotation, assign weights to versions
4. Click **Save**

## Rule Parameters

### Min Separation
- Minimum time (in minutes) between spots
- Prevents spots from playing too close together
- Example: 30 minutes means spots must be at least 30 minutes apart

### Max Per Hour
- Maximum number of spots that can play in one hour
- Prevents over-saturation
- Example: 2 means no more than 2 spots per hour

### Max Per Day
- Maximum number of spots that can play in one day
- Controls daily frequency
- Example: 10 means no more than 10 spots per day

## Applying Rules

Rotation rules can be applied to:
- **Campaigns**: All spots in a campaign follow the rule
- **Dayparts**: All spots in a daypart follow the rule
- **Orders**: All spots in an order follow the rule
- **Copy Versions**: Multiple versions of copy rotate according to rule

## Best Practices

- Set appropriate separation times (30-60 minutes typical)
- Use max per hour/day to prevent over-saturation
- Test rotation rules before applying broadly
- Document special rules for reference
- Review rules periodically for effectiveness

concepts.title: Sales Representatives
concepts.description: Understanding sales reps and their role in the system
concepts.content:
# Sales Representatives

## What is a Sales Rep?

A Sales Rep (Sales Representative) is a person who sells advertising and manages client relationships. Each order is typically assigned to a sales rep who is responsible for:
- Building relationships with advertisers
- Creating orders
- Managing accounts
- Following up on payments
- Maintaining client satisfaction

## Sales Rep Records

Sales rep records contain:
- **Name/Username**: How they're identified in the system
- **Contact Information**: Email, phone
- **Active Status**: Whether they're currently active
- **Orders**: All orders they've created

## Creating a Sales Rep

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Sales Reps**
2. Click **Add Sales Rep**
3. Enter:
   - **Username/Name**: How they'll appear in the system
   - **Email**: Contact email
   - **Phone**: Contact number
   - **Active**: Check to enable
4. Click **Save**

## Assigning Sales Reps to Orders

When creating an order:
1. Select the **Sales Rep** from the dropdown
2. This rep is credited with the sale
3. They'll be associated with the order
4. Reports can show sales by rep

## Why Sales Reps Matter

- **Accountability**: Track who sold what
- **Reporting**: Generate sales reports by rep
- **Commission**: Calculate commissions based on sales
- **Support**: Know who to contact for account questions
- **Performance**: Track individual sales performance

## Sales Rep vs User

- **User**: Someone who can log into the system (sales rep, traffic manager, etc.)
- **Sales Rep**: A specific role/record for tracking sales

A sales rep may or may not be a system user. If they are a user, they can log in and create orders themselves.

## Best Practices

- Create sales rep records for all active sales people
- Assign sales rep to every order
- Keep sales rep records up to date
- Mark inactive when sales rep leaves
- Use for commission tracking and reporting

concepts.title: Agencies and Advertisers: Understanding the Relationship
concepts.description: How agencies work with advertisers and when to use each
concepts.content:
# Agencies and Advertisers: Understanding the Relationship

## What is an Advertiser?

An **Advertiser** is the business or organization that wants to advertise on the radio. This is the actual client - the company paying for the commercials.

**Examples**:
- Local restaurant
- Car dealership
- Real estate agency
- Non-profit organization

## What is an Agency?

An **Agency** is an advertising firm that represents advertisers and buys commercial time on their behalf. Agencies act as intermediaries between advertisers and radio stations.

**Examples**:
- Full-service advertising agency
- Media buying agency
- Marketing firm

## How They Work Together

### Direct Advertisers (No Agency)

Some businesses buy advertising directly from the radio station:

- **Order Structure**:
  - Advertiser: Required (the business)
  - Agency: None
  - Billing: Invoice sent directly to advertiser

**Example**:
- Advertiser: "Joe's Pizza"
- Agency: None
- Invoice goes to: Joe's Pizza

### Agency-Represented Advertisers

Some businesses work through advertising agencies:

- **Order Structure**:
  - Advertiser: Required (the business being advertised)
  - Agency: Required (the agency representing them)
  - Billing: Invoice typically sent to agency (who then bills the advertiser)

**Example**:
- Advertiser: "Joe's Pizza"
- Agency: "ABC Advertising Agency"
- Invoice goes to: ABC Advertising Agency

## Key Points

1. **Agencies are NOT tied to advertisers** - They are separate entities
2. **An order can have BOTH an advertiser AND an agency**
3. **The advertiser is always required** - This is the business being advertised
4. **The agency is optional** - Only include if the advertiser is represented by an agency
5. **Billing typically goes to the agency** if one is specified, otherwise to the advertiser

## When to Create an Agency Record

Create an agency when:
- An advertiser tells you they work with an agency
- A media buyer contacts you on behalf of a client
- You receive orders from an agency representing multiple clients
- Billing should go to the agency, not the advertiser directly

## Agency Commission

Agencies may receive commission:
- Commission rate is set in the agency record
- Commission is calculated on orders
- Typically 15% of gross order value

## Creating Records

### Creating an Advertiser

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Advertisers**
2. Click **Add Advertiser**
3. Enter advertiser information:
   - Business name
   - Contact information
   - Payment terms
   - Credit limit

### Creating an Agency

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Agencies**
2. Click **Add Agency**
3. Enter agency information:
   - Agency name
   - Contact information
   - Commission rate (if applicable)

### Creating an Order with Agency

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Orders**
2. Click **New Order**
3. Select:
   - **Advertiser**: The business being advertised (required)
   - **Agency**: The agency representing them (optional)
4. Complete rest of order details

## Billing Considerations

- **Direct Advertiser**: Invoice sent to advertiser
- **Agency-Represented**: Invoice typically sent to agency
- **Payment Terms**: May differ between direct and agency accounts
- **Credit Limits**: Tracked separately for advertisers and agencies

## Best Practices

- Always create the advertiser record first (the actual business)
- Create agency record only if advertiser is represented by one
- Verify billing address (advertiser vs agency)
- Track which advertisers work with which agencies
- Understand commission structure if applicable
- Communicate clearly about who will receive invoices

concepts.title: Invoice Lifecycle
concepts.description: Understanding the invoice process from creation to payment
concepts.content:
# Invoice Lifecycle

## Invoice Statuses

### DRAFT
- Invoice created but not finalized
- Can be edited
- Not sent to customer

### SENT
- Invoice emailed to advertiser/agency
- PDF attached
- Due date set
- Waiting for payment

### PAID
- Full payment received
- Invoice closed
- No further action needed

### PARTIAL
- Some payment received
- Balance still owed
- Remaining amount tracked

### OVERDUE
- Past due date
- No payment received
- Requires follow-up

## Invoice Process

### 1. Generation
- Created from completed order
- Includes all aired spots
- Calculates totals and tax

### 2. Review
- Billing reviews for accuracy
- Verifies spot counts
- Checks pricing

### 3. Sending
- Email sent to advertiser/agency
- PDF invoice attached
- Status updates to SENT

### 4. Payment Tracking
- Payments recorded as received
- Status updates based on payment
- AR aging tracked

### 5. Follow-up
- Overdue invoices followed up
- Payment reminders sent
- Collections if needed

## Payment Terms

Common terms:
- **Net 30**: Payment due 30 days after invoice date
- **Net 15**: Payment due 15 days after invoice date
- **Due on Receipt**: Payment due immediately

## AR Aging

Invoices tracked by age:
- **Current**: 0-30 days
- **31-60 days**: Slightly overdue
- **61-90 days**: Overdue
- **Over 90 days**: Seriously overdue

## Best Practices

- Generate invoices promptly
- Send on schedule
- Track payments accurately
- Follow up on overdue accounts
- Maintain good records

concepts.title: Traffic Logs
concepts.description: Understanding traffic logs and activity tracking
concepts.content:
# Traffic Logs

## What are Traffic Logs?

Traffic Logs are records of all activities and changes in the traffic system. They track:
- Order creation and modifications
- Spot scheduling changes
- Copy uploads and assignments
- Log generation and publishing
- User actions and system events

## Why Traffic Logs Matter

- **Audit Trail**: See who did what and when
- **Troubleshooting**: Track down issues or errors
- **Compliance**: Maintain records for regulatory requirements
- **Accountability**: Know who made changes
- **History**: Review past actions and decisions

## What Gets Logged

### Order Activities
- Order created
- Order modified
- Order approved/rejected
- Order status changes

### Spot Activities
- Spots scheduled
- Spots moved
- Spots cancelled
- Spot status changes

### Copy Activities
- Copy uploaded
- Copy assigned to order
- Copy expired
- Copy deleted

### Log Activities
- Daily log generated
- Log published
- Log edited
- Log revisions

### System Activities
- User logins
- Settings changes
- Configuration updates

## Viewing Traffic Logs

1. Navigate to **Traffic > Traffic Logs**
2. View logs by:
   - Date range
   - User
   - Activity type
   - Related order/spot/log
3. Filter and search logs
4. Export logs for reporting

## Log Details

Each log entry includes:
- **Timestamp**: When it happened
- **User**: Who performed the action
- **Activity Type**: What type of action
- **Message**: Description of what happened
- **Related Items**: Links to orders, spots, etc.
- **Metadata**: Additional details

## Best Practices

- Review logs regularly
- Use logs for troubleshooting
- Keep logs for compliance
- Export important logs
- Monitor for unusual activity

concepts.title: Voice Tracking
concepts.description: Recording and managing voice tracks for automation
concepts.content:
# Voice Tracking

## What is Voice Tracking?

Voice Tracking is the process of recording voice elements (DJ breaks, liners, IDs, etc.) for use in automated programming. Instead of live broadcasts, pre-recorded voice tracks are inserted into the log.

## Why Use Voice Tracking?

- **Consistency**: Same voice quality and style
- **Efficiency**: Record once, use many times
- **Flexibility**: Record in advance
- **Quality**: Can re-record until perfect
- **Automation**: Works with automated systems

## Voice Track Types

### DJ Breaks
- Personalities talking between songs
- Station IDs and promos
- Weather, traffic, news teases

### Liners
- Short station promos
- Taglines and slogans
- Quick announcements

### Station IDs
- Legal identification
- Frequency and call letters
- Required by FCC

### Live Read Scripts
- Commercial scripts read by talent
- More personal than pre-produced ads
- Integrated into programming

## Recording Voice Tracks

1. Navigate to **Voice > Voice Recorder**
2. Select track type
3. Enter script or notes
4. Click **Record**
5. Record your voice track
6. Review and approve
7. Save to library

## Using Voice Tracks

Voice tracks are:
- Assigned to specific times in logs
- Inserted automatically during log generation
- Replaced when new versions are recorded
- Archived when expired

## Best Practices

- Record in quiet environment
- Use consistent microphone and settings
- Review tracks before saving
- Keep multiple versions if needed
- Archive old tracks
- Label tracks clearly

concepts.title: Order Approval Process
concepts.description: Understanding why orders need approval and how the approval process works
concepts.content:
# Order Approval Process

## Why Orders Need Approval

Orders require approval before spots can be scheduled to ensure:
- **Credit Limits**: Advertiser has sufficient credit available
- **Pricing Accuracy**: Rates are correct and appropriate
- **Copy Availability**: Commercial audio or scripts are ready
- **Contract Terms**: All terms are acceptable
- **Compliance**: Orders meet station policies and regulations

Think of approval as a quality check before committing to air commercials.

## Who Approves Orders?

Typically, **Sales Managers** approve orders. They review:
- Order details and pricing
- Advertiser credit standing
- Copy availability
- Contract terms
- Special requirements

## Approval Statuses

### PENDING
- Order submitted by sales person
- Waiting for sales manager review
- Cannot schedule spots yet
- Sales manager notified

### APPROVED
- Sales manager reviewed and approved
- Order is ready for scheduling
- Traffic manager can now schedule spots
- Order moves to ACTIVE status when spots are scheduled

### REJECTED
- Sales manager found issues
- Order needs corrections
- Returns to sales person for changes
- Cannot schedule spots until re-approved

### NOT_REQUIRED
- Some orders don't need approval
- Typically for small orders or trusted advertisers
- Can proceed directly to scheduling

## What Gets Checked During Approval

### Credit Limits
- Is advertiser within credit limit?
- Will this order exceed the limit?
- Is payment history good?

### Pricing
- Are rates correct?
- Is total value accurate?
- Are discounts appropriate?

### Copy Availability
- Is commercial audio uploaded?
- Are scripts ready?
- Are special requirements met?

### Contract Terms
- Are dates reasonable?
- Is spot count achievable?
- Are rate types appropriate?

## Approval Process Flow

1. **Sales Person** creates order (status: DRAFT)
2. **Sales Person** submits for approval (status: PENDING)
3. **Sales Manager** reviews order
4. **Sales Manager** approves or rejects
5. If **APPROVED**: Order available for scheduling
6. If **REJECTED**: Order returns to sales person with notes

## How Approval Affects Scheduling

- **Before Approval**: Traffic manager cannot schedule spots
- **After Approval**: Traffic manager can schedule spots
- **Rejected Orders**: Must be fixed and re-approved before scheduling

## Best Practices

- Submit orders for approval promptly
- Ensure copy is uploaded before submitting
- Check credit limits before creating orders
- Respond quickly to rejection notes
- Communicate with sales manager about special requirements

## Related Concepts

- See "Order Statuses Explained" for complete status workflow
- See "Credit Limits and Payment Terms" for credit information

concepts.title: Order Statuses Explained
concepts.description: Understanding what each order status means and when it changes
concepts.content:
# Order Statuses Explained

## Overview

Order statuses track where an order is in its lifecycle, from creation to completion. Understanding statuses helps you know what actions are possible and what comes next.

## Order Statuses

### DRAFT

**What it means**: Order is being created or edited, not yet submitted.

**Characteristics**:
- Still being worked on
- Can be edited freely
- Not submitted for approval
- Spots cannot be scheduled

**Who changes it**: Sales person

**Next step**: Submit for approval (changes to PENDING)

### PENDING

**What it means**: Order submitted for approval, waiting for sales manager review.

**Characteristics**:
- Submitted for approval
- Awaiting sales manager review
- Cannot be edited (or requires unlock)
- Spots cannot be scheduled

**Who changes it**: Sales person (when submitting)

**Next step**: Sales manager approves or rejects

### APPROVED

**What it means**: Sales manager approved the order, ready for scheduling.

**Characteristics**:
- Approved by sales manager
- Ready for traffic manager
- Can schedule spots
- Copy should be available

**Who changes it**: Sales manager (when approving)

**Next step**: Traffic manager schedules spots (changes to ACTIVE)

### ACTIVE

**What it means**: Spots are scheduled and airing.

**Characteristics**:
- Spots are scheduled
- Commercials are airing
- Order is "live"
- Cannot be cancelled without consequences

**Who changes it**: System (when spots are scheduled)

**Next step**: All spots air (changes to COMPLETED)

### COMPLETED

**What it means**: All spots have aired, order is finished.

**Characteristics**:
- All spots have aired
- Order fulfilled
- Ready for invoicing
- No further scheduling needed

**Who changes it**: System (when all spots air)

**Next step**: Billing generates invoice

### CANCELLED

**What it means**: Order was cancelled before completion.

**Characteristics**:
- Order cancelled
- No spots will air
- May have cancellation fees
- Cannot be reactivated

**Who changes it**: Sales manager or authorized user

**When it happens**: Advertiser cancels, contract issues, or other problems

## Status Flow

Typical flow:
1. **DRAFT** → Sales person creates order
2. **PENDING** → Sales person submits for approval
3. **APPROVED** → Sales manager approves
4. **ACTIVE** → Traffic manager schedules spots
5. **COMPLETED** → All spots have aired

Alternative flows:
- **PENDING** → **REJECTED** → Back to **DRAFT** (after fixes)
- **APPROVED** → **CANCELLED** (if cancelled before scheduling)
- **ACTIVE** → **CANCELLED** (if cancelled after scheduling)

## Who Can Change Statuses

- **Sales Person**: DRAFT → PENDING
- **Sales Manager**: PENDING → APPROVED or REJECTED
- **System**: APPROVED → ACTIVE (when spots scheduled)
- **System**: ACTIVE → COMPLETED (when all spots air)
- **Authorized Users**: Can cancel orders

## Status and Workflow

Each status determines:
- What actions are possible
- Who can work on the order
- What the next step should be
- Whether spots can be scheduled

## Best Practices

- Keep orders in appropriate status
- Don't leave orders in DRAFT unnecessarily
- Submit for approval promptly
- Monitor order status regularly
- Understand what each status means for your role

## Related Concepts

- See "Order Approval Process" for approval details
- See "Spot Statuses and Lifecycle" for spot status information

concepts.title: Spot Statuses and Lifecycle
concepts.description: Understanding how spots move through their lifecycle and what each status means
concepts.content:
# Spot Statuses and Lifecycle

## Overview

Spots have their own statuses that track whether they've aired, were missed, or need makegoods. Understanding spot statuses helps you track contract fulfillment and billing accuracy.

## Spot Statuses

### SCHEDULED

**What it means**: Spot is scheduled to air at a specific date and time.

**Characteristics**:
- Has scheduled date and time
- Assigned to an order
- Copy should be available
- Ready to air

**When it happens**: Traffic manager schedules the spot

**Next step**: Spot airs (changes to AIRED) or doesn't air (changes to MISSED)

### AIRED

**What it means**: Spot successfully aired at its scheduled time (or close to it).

**Characteristics**:
- Commercial played on-air
- Contract fulfilled for this spot
- Will be included on invoice
- Actual air time recorded

**When it happens**: Automation system confirms playback

**Next step**: Included in billing

### MISSED

**What it means**: Spot was scheduled but did not air.

**Characteristics**:
- Was scheduled but didn't play
- Contract not fulfilled
- May need makegood
- Reason should be documented

**When it happens**:
- Technical failure
- Programming preemption
- Station error
- Missing copy

**Next step**: Create makegood (changes to MAKEGOOD)

### MAKEGOOD

**What it means**: This spot is a free replacement for a missed spot.

**Characteristics**:
- Free to advertiser
- Replaces a MISSED spot
- Should be comparable placement
- Tracks contract fulfillment

**When it happens**: Traffic manager creates makegood for missed spot

**Next step**: Makegood spot airs (changes to AIRED)

## Spot Lifecycle

Typical lifecycle:
1. **SCHEDULED** → Traffic manager schedules spot
2. **AIRED** → Spot plays on-air
3. Included in billing

Problem lifecycle:
1. **SCHEDULED** → Spot scheduled
2. **MISSED** → Spot doesn't air
3. **MAKEGOOD** → Replacement spot created
4. **AIRED** → Makegood spot plays
5. Included in billing (makegood at $0)

## What Triggers Status Changes

### SCHEDULED → AIRED
- Automation system confirms playback
- Actual air time recorded
- System updates status automatically

### SCHEDULED → MISSED
- System detects spot didn't air
- Traffic manager marks as missed
- Reason documented

### MISSED → MAKEGOOD
- Traffic manager creates makegood
- New spot scheduled to replace missed one
- Linked to original missed spot

### MAKEGOOD → AIRED
- Makegood spot airs
- Contract fulfilled
- Free to advertiser

## When Spots Don't Air

Common reasons:
- **Technical Issues**: Equipment failure, power outage
- **Programming Changes**: Breaking news, special programming
- **Preemption**: Higher priority content
- **Station Error**: Scheduling mistake
- **Missing Copy**: No audio file available

What happens:
1. Spot marked as MISSED
2. Reason documented
3. Makegood created (if appropriate)
4. Replacement spot scheduled
5. Advertiser notified (if significant)

## Status and Billing

- **AIRED spots**: Included on invoice at full rate
- **MISSED spots**: Not included (or credited)
- **MAKEGOOD spots**: Included at $0 (for record keeping)

## Best Practices

- Monitor spot statuses regularly
- Create makegoods promptly for missed spots
- Document reasons for missed spots
- Ensure makegoods are comparable placement
- Track all makegoods for reporting

## Related Concepts

- See "Makegoods" for detailed makegood information
- See "Preemption" for preemption details
- See "Order Statuses Explained" for order status information

concepts.title: Credit Limits and Payment Terms
concepts.description: Understanding credit limits, payment terms, and how they affect orders
concepts.content:
# Credit Limits and Payment Terms

## What is a Credit Limit?

A credit limit is the maximum amount an advertiser can owe the station at one time. It's like a credit card limit - once reached, no new orders can be approved until payment is received.

## Why Credit Limits Matter

- **Risk Management**: Protects station from bad debt
- **Order Approval**: Orders exceeding limit cannot be approved
- **Cash Flow**: Ensures timely payment
- **Account Management**: Helps track advertiser financial health

## How Credit Limits Work

### Setting Credit Limits

When creating an advertiser:
1. Review advertiser's financial history
2. Set appropriate credit limit
3. Consider:
   - Payment history
   - Business size
   - Industry standards
   - Station policy

### Checking Credit

Before approving orders:
1. System checks current balance
2. Calculates: Current Balance + New Order Value
3. Compares to credit limit
4. Approves or rejects based on limit

### When Limit is Exceeded

If order would exceed limit:
- Order cannot be approved
- Sales manager sees warning
- Options:
  - Request payment on existing invoices
  - Increase credit limit (if justified)
  - Require payment before order approval

## Payment Terms

Payment terms specify when invoices are due.

### Common Payment Terms

**Net 30**
- Payment due 30 days after invoice date
- Most common term
- Example: Invoice dated Jan 1, due Jan 31

**Net 15**
- Payment due 15 days after invoice date
- Faster payment
- Example: Invoice dated Jan 1, due Jan 16

**Due on Receipt**
- Payment due immediately
- No grace period
- Used for new or risky accounts

**Net 60**
- Payment due 60 days after invoice date
- Longer terms
- Used for large accounts or special arrangements

## How Payment Terms Affect Orders

### Order Approval
- Sales manager considers payment terms
- Accounts with poor payment history may need stricter terms
- New accounts may require "Due on Receipt"

### Credit Management
- Accounts with Net 30 may have higher credit limits
- Accounts with "Due on Receipt" may have lower limits
- Payment history affects future terms

## Setting Payment Terms

When creating an advertiser:
1. Consider industry standards
2. Review payment history (if existing)
3. Set terms appropriate for account
4. Update if payment behavior changes

## Best Practices

- Set realistic credit limits
- Review limits regularly
- Monitor payment history
- Update terms based on behavior
- Communicate clearly about terms
- Enforce limits consistently

## Related Concepts

- See "Order Approval Process" for how credit affects approval
- See "Invoice Lifecycle" for payment tracking

concepts.title: Break Structures
concepts.description: Understanding how commercial breaks are structured and why positions matter
concepts.content:
# Break Structures

## What is a Break Structure?

A break structure defines when commercial breaks occur within each hour and how many spots can fit in each break. It's like a template that says "at 15 minutes past the hour, there's a 2-minute break with 3 spots."

## Why Break Structures Matter

- **Consistency**: Ensures breaks happen at predictable times
- **Position Assignment**: Determines A, B, C positions
- **Inventory Management**: Defines available commercial time
- **Pricing**: A-position spots cost more
- **Programming Flow**: Maintains consistent programming rhythm

## How Breaks Are Structured

### Break Positions (A, B, C, etc.)

- **A Position**: First spot in the break (premium)
- **B Position**: Second spot in the break
- **C Position**: Third spot in the break
- **D, E, F...**: Additional positions

### Break Timing

Breaks are defined by:
- **Hour**: Which hour of the day (0-23)
- **Time Offset**: Seconds from hour start (e.g., 900 = 15 minutes)
- **Duration**: How long the break lasts
- **Spot Count**: How many spots fit in break

### Example Break Structure

**8:00 AM Hour**:
- Break 1: 8:15:00 (15 minutes past hour)
  - 3 spots, 2 minutes total
  - Positions: A, B, C
- Break 2: 8:45:00 (45 minutes past hour)
  - 2 spots, 1.5 minutes total
  - Positions: A, B

## Break Structures and Clock Templates

Break structures work with clock templates:
- **Clock Templates**: Define overall hour structure (music, news, breaks)
- **Break Structures**: Define specific break timing and positions
- **Together**: Create complete programming schedule

## How Spots Are Placed in Breaks

1. Traffic manager schedules spot
2. System identifies appropriate break
3. System assigns position (A, B, C, etc.)
4. Position based on:
   - Order requirements
   - Rate structure
   - Advertiser preferences
   - Availability

## Position Pricing

- **A Position**: Premium rate (highest)
- **B Position**: Standard rate
- **C Position**: Standard or lower rate
- **Later Positions**: Lower rates

Why A-position costs more:
- Listeners most likely to hear it
- Highest retention rate
- Premium placement

## Break Structure by Hour

Different hours may have different break structures:
- **Morning Drive**: More breaks, more spots
- **Midday**: Moderate breaks
- **Evening**: Fewer breaks
- **Overnight**: Minimal breaks

## Creating Break Structures

1. Navigate to break structure management
2. Select hour (0-23)
3. Define break times
4. Set number of positions
5. Set break duration
6. Save structure

## Best Practices

- Keep break structures consistent
- Align with clock templates
- Consider listener experience
- Balance commercial time with programming
- Review and adjust based on performance

## Related Concepts

- See "Dayparts and Break Positions" for position details
- See "Clock Templates" for overall programming structure

concepts.title: Inventory Management
concepts.description: Understanding available commercial time and how inventory is tracked
concepts.content:
# Inventory Management

## What is Inventory?

In radio, inventory is the available commercial time you can sell. Think of it like seats in a theater - there are a limited number of spots available each hour, and once sold, they're gone.

## Why Inventory Management Matters

- **Pricing**: Scarcity affects rates (less available = higher rates)
- **Sales Planning**: Know what you can sell
- **Revenue Optimization**: Fill inventory efficiently
- **Conflict Prevention**: Avoid overselling

## How Inventory is Tracked

### By Date and Hour

- Each hour has a certain amount of commercial time
- System tracks:
  - **Available**: Open time slots
  - **Booked**: Time sold to orders
  - **Sold Out**: No more time available

### By Daypart

- Inventory tracked by daypart (Morning Drive, Afternoon Drive, etc.)
- Different dayparts have different availability
- Prime time has less availability (higher demand)

### By Break Position

- Inventory tracked by position (A, B, C, etc.)
- A-positions are most limited (premium)
- Later positions more available

## Inventory States

### Available

- Time slot is open
- Can be sold
- No spots scheduled

### Booked

- Time slot is sold
- Spot scheduled
- Part of an order

### Sold Out

- No more time available
- Cannot schedule additional spots
- May need to wait for cancellations

## How Inventory Affects Pricing

### Supply and Demand

- **High Availability**: Lower rates (more supply)
- **Low Availability**: Higher rates (less supply)
- **Sold Out**: Premium rates if any become available

### Dynamic Pricing

- Rates may increase as inventory decreases
- Prime time sells out first
- Off-peak may have more availability

## Using Inventory Reports

### Availability Reports

- See what's available by:
  - Date range
  - Hour
  - Daypart
  - Position

### Utilization Reports

- See how much inventory is used
- Percentage booked
- Remaining availability

### Heatmaps

- Visual representation of availability
- Color-coded by availability level
- Easy to see patterns

## Inventory Planning

### Short Term

- Fill current week/month
- Balance across dayparts
- Maximize revenue

### Long Term

- Forecast future availability
- Plan sales campaigns
- Identify slow periods

## Best Practices

- Monitor inventory regularly
- Balance ROS and daypart orders
- Fill slow periods with ROS
- Reserve prime time for premium orders
- Track utilization trends
- Use inventory data for pricing decisions

## Related Concepts

- See "Daypart Management" for daypart details
- See "Break Structures" for break information
- See "Reports and Analytics" for inventory reports

concepts.title: Political Advertising and FCC Compliance
concepts.description: Understanding special rules and requirements for political advertising
concepts.content:
# Political Advertising and FCC Compliance

## Overview

Political advertising has special rules and requirements mandated by the FCC (Federal Communications Commission). These rules ensure transparency, prevent fraud, and maintain public access to political information.

## What is Political Advertising?

Political advertising includes:
- **Candidate Ads**: Ads for political candidates
- **Issue Advocacy**: Ads about political issues
- **Ballot Measures**: Ads for or against ballot initiatives
- **Political Parties**: Party promotion ads

## FCC Requirements

### Disclaimers

All political ads must include disclaimers:
- **Who Paid**: "Paid for by [sponsor name]"
- **Contact Info**: Sponsor contact information
- **Clear Identification**: Must be clearly audible

### No Substitution

- Political ads **cannot be substituted**
- Must air exactly as provided
- Cannot be replaced with other content
- Even if advertiser requests change

### Priority Scheduling

- Political ads get priority in scheduling
- Must be placed as requested
- Cannot be bumped for other content
- During political windows, priority increases

### Archiving Requirements

- **2-Year Retention**: Must keep records for 2 years
- **Archive Location**: Must document where archived
- **Access**: Must be available for public inspection
- **Content**: Must archive actual audio that aired

## Political Windows

Political windows are specific time periods:
- **Before Elections**: Typically 45-60 days before
- **Higher Priority**: Even more priority during windows
- **No Preemption**: Cannot be preempted during windows
- **Strict Scheduling**: Must air as scheduled

## Handling Political Orders

### Creating Political Orders

1. Identify order as political
2. Create political record
3. Enter sponsor information
4. Set political window dates
5. Mark as no substitution
6. Set priority scheduling

### Required Information

- **Sponsor Name**: Who paid for the ad
- **Sponsor ID**: FEC ID or similar
- **Office Sought**: What office candidate is running for
- **Disclaimers**: Required disclaimer text
- **Political Window**: Start and end dates

### Compliance Tracking

- **Compliance Status**: Track if compliant
- **Disclaimers Included**: Verify disclaimers in copy
- **Archive Location**: Where files are stored
- **Archive Date**: When archived

## Special Rules

### No Preemption

- Political ads cannot be preempted
- Even for breaking news
- Must air as scheduled
- Exception: Only if legally required

### No Substitution

- Cannot replace political ad with another
- Must air exact copy provided
- Cannot modify content
- Even if advertiser requests

### Priority Scheduling

- Political ads scheduled first
- Before other commercial content
- During political windows, highest priority
- Traffic manager must accommodate

## Archiving Process

1. **Record Airing**: Document when ad aired
2. **Save Copy**: Archive actual audio file
3. **Store Securely**: Keep in accessible location
4. **Document Location**: Record where stored
5. **Retain 2 Years**: Keep for required period
6. **Public Access**: Make available for inspection

## Best Practices

- Identify political ads immediately
- Create political records promptly
- Verify disclaimers before airing
- Archive properly and securely
- Track compliance status
- Document everything
- Train staff on requirements

## Legal Considerations

- FCC violations can result in fines
- Public inspection requirements
- Record keeping is mandatory
- Consult legal counsel for questions

## Related Concepts

- See "Order Approval Process" for approval workflow
- See "Makegoods" for handling issues (though political ads have special rules)

concepts.title: Spot Lengths Explained
concepts.description: Understanding why spots are 15, 30, or 60 seconds and how length affects everything
concepts.content:
# Spot Lengths Explained

## Standard Spot Lengths

Radio commercials come in standard lengths:
- **15 seconds**: Short, quick message
- **30 seconds**: Most common, standard length
- **60 seconds**: Longer, more detailed message

## Why These Lengths?

### Industry Standard

- Stations plan breaks around these lengths
- Equipment and systems designed for these
- Advertisers expect these options
- Easy to calculate and schedule

### Break Structure

- Breaks are timed for standard lengths
- Example: 2-minute break = 4 × 30-second spots
- Mixing lengths requires careful timing
- Non-standard lengths complicate scheduling

## How Length Affects Pricing

### General Rule

- **Longer = More Expensive**: 60-second costs more than 30-second
- **But Not Double**: 60-second doesn't cost exactly 2× 30-second
- **Rate Structure**: Each length has its own rate

### Pricing Examples

- **30-second**: $100 per spot (example)
- **60-second**: $180 per spot (not $200)
- **15-second**: $60 per spot (not $50)

Why not proportional?
- Longer spots take more inventory
- But pricing includes production value
- Market demand affects rates

## Which Length is Most Common?

### 30 Seconds

- **Most Popular**: Standard length for most ads
- **Good Balance**: Enough time for message, not too long
- **Best Value**: Good cost-to-message ratio
- **Easy Scheduling**: Fits standard break structures

### 60 Seconds

- **Less Common**: Used for detailed messages
- **Higher Cost**: More expensive per spot
- **Special Cases**: Complex products, testimonials

### 15 Seconds

- **Least Common**: Quick reminders or tags
- **Lower Cost**: Cheaper option
- **Limited Message**: Very brief

## How to Choose the Right Length

### Consider the Message

- **Simple Message**: 15 or 30 seconds
- **Complex Product**: 60 seconds
- **Quick Reminder**: 15 seconds
- **Full Story**: 60 seconds

### Consider the Budget

- **Limited Budget**: 15 or 30 seconds
- **More Budget**: 60 seconds for impact
- **Frequency vs Length**: More 30-second spots or fewer 60-second?

### Consider the Audience

- **Attention Span**: Shorter may be better
- **Time of Day**: Drive time listeners may prefer shorter
- **Message Complexity**: Complex needs more time

## Length and Break Structure

### Standard Breaks

- Breaks designed for standard lengths
- 2-minute break = 4 × 30-second spots
- 1.5-minute break = 3 × 30-second spots
- Mixing lengths requires calculation

### Mixing Lengths

- Can mix 15, 30, and 60-second spots
- Must total break duration
- Example: 30 + 30 + 60 = 2 minutes
- Traffic manager calculates timing

## Production Considerations

### 15-Second Spots

- Very tight timing
- Must be concise
- Often used as tags or reminders
- Lower production cost

### 30-Second Spots

- Standard production
- Good for most messages
- Most common length
- Standard production cost

### 60-Second Spots

- More production time
- Can tell fuller story
- Higher production cost
- More detailed message

## Best Practices

- Use 30-second for most campaigns
- Consider 60-second for complex products
- Use 15-second for reminders or tags
- Match length to message complexity
- Consider budget and frequency trade-offs

## Related Concepts

- See "Break Structures" for how length fits in breaks
- See "Rate Types Explained" for pricing information

concepts.title: Program Rate Type
concepts.description: Understanding PROGRAM rate type and when to use it
concepts.content:
# Program Rate Type

## What is PROGRAM Rate Type?

PROGRAM is a rate type where spots are scheduled during specific radio programs or shows. Unlike daypart (which is time-based) or ROS (which is flexible), PROGRAM rate type ties spots to specific program content.

## How PROGRAM Differs from Other Rate Types

### PROGRAM vs ROS

- **ROS**: Any time, any program
- **PROGRAM**: Specific program only
- **PROGRAM**: Usually higher rate (targeted)
- **ROS**: More flexible, lower rate

### PROGRAM vs Daypart

- **Daypart**: Time-based (Morning Drive, etc.)
- **PROGRAM**: Content-based (specific show)
- **Daypart**: Multiple programs in time period
- **PROGRAM**: One specific program

### PROGRAM vs Fixed Time

- **Fixed Time**: Exact clock time
- **PROGRAM**: Program may air at different times
- **Fixed Time**: Time never changes
- **PROGRAM**: Time may vary with program schedule

## When to Use PROGRAM Rate Type

### Program-Specific Targeting

- Advertiser wants specific audience
- Program has ideal demographics
- Content alignment (e.g., sports show for sports advertiser)
- Higher engagement with program listeners

### Premium Placement

- Advertiser wants association with program
- Program has loyal audience
- Willing to pay premium rate
- Brand alignment important

### Special Programming

- Talk shows with engaged listeners
- Sports programs with passionate fans
- News programs with attentive audience
- Specialty shows with targeted demographics

## How PROGRAM Affects Scheduling

### Traffic Manager Considerations

- Must schedule during specific program
- Program schedule may vary
- Must coordinate with program director
- May need to adjust if program moves

### Scheduling Challenges

- Program may be preempted
- Program time may change
- Limited spots available per program
- Must track program schedule changes

## PROGRAM Pricing

### Typically Higher Rates

- More targeted than ROS
- Specific audience
- Premium placement
- Usually higher than daypart rates

### Rate Factors

- Program popularity
- Audience demographics
- Program content alignment
- Advertiser demand

## Best Practices

- Use for program-specific targeting
- Verify program schedule stability
- Coordinate with program director
- Monitor for program changes
- Communicate schedule changes to advertiser

## Related Concepts

- See "Rate Types Explained" for comparison of all rate types
- See "Daypart Management" for time-based scheduling

concepts.title: Conflict Resolution
concepts.description: Understanding scheduling conflicts and how to resolve them
concepts.content:
# Conflict Resolution

## What are Scheduling Conflicts?

Scheduling conflicts occur when spots cannot be scheduled as planned due to:
- **Time Overlaps**: Multiple spots scheduled at same time
- **Oversell**: Too many spots in one hour
- **Missing Copy**: Spot scheduled but no audio file
- **Break Capacity**: More spots than break can hold
- **Rate Type Violations**: Spot doesn't meet rate type requirements

## Types of Conflicts

### Time Overlap

**What it is**: Two or more spots scheduled at the exact same time.

**Why it happens**:
- Manual scheduling error
- System glitch
- Last-minute changes

**How to resolve**:
- Move one spot to different time
- Check both orders for requirements
- Ensure comparable placement

### Oversell

**What it is**: More spots scheduled in an hour than available inventory.

**Why it happens**:
- Inventory calculation error
- Multiple orders for same time
- Break structure changed

**How to resolve**:
- Move spots to other hours
- Check inventory availability
- Verify break structure

### Missing Copy

**What it is**: Spot scheduled but commercial audio file not available.

**Why it happens**:
- Copy not uploaded yet
- Copy expired
- File error

**How to resolve**:
- Upload copy immediately
- Use temporary copy if available
- Reschedule spot until copy ready

### Break Capacity

**What it is**: More spots assigned to break than positions available.

**Why it happens**:
- Break structure allows 3 spots, 4 assigned
- Position assignment error

**How to resolve**:
- Move spot to different break
- Adjust break structure (if possible)
- Reassign positions

### Rate Type Violations

**What it is**: Spot scheduled outside rate type requirements.

**Examples**:
- Daypart order scheduled in wrong daypart
- Fixed time order at wrong time
- PROGRAM order in wrong program

**How to resolve**:
- Move to correct time/daypart/program
- Verify order requirements
- Check rate type settings

## How System Detects Conflicts

### Automatic Detection

- System checks when scheduling
- Warns about conflicts
- Prevents invalid scheduling
- Highlights conflicts in interface

### Conflict Warnings

- Visual indicators
- Error messages
- Cannot save until resolved
- Lists all conflicts

## How to Resolve Conflicts

### Step 1: Identify Conflict

- Review conflict list
- Understand what's wrong
- Check order requirements

### Step 2: Determine Solution

- Can spot be moved?
- Is comparable placement available?
- Does it meet order requirements?

### Step 3: Make Changes

- Move conflicting spot
- Adjust scheduling
- Upload missing copy
- Fix break assignments

### Step 4: Verify Resolution

- Check conflict list again
- Ensure no new conflicts
- Verify order requirements met
- Confirm with traffic manager

## Best Practices for Avoiding Conflicts

### Before Scheduling

- Check inventory availability
- Verify copy is uploaded
- Review order requirements
- Confirm break structures

### During Scheduling

- Use system conflict detection
- Don't ignore warnings
- Verify each spot placement
- Check for oversells

### Regular Monitoring

- Review schedule daily
- Check for new conflicts
- Resolve promptly
- Document resolutions

## Conflict Resolution Workflow

1. **Detect**: System or manual review identifies conflict
2. **Analyze**: Understand conflict type and cause
3. **Plan**: Determine best resolution
4. **Execute**: Make necessary changes
5. **Verify**: Confirm conflict resolved
6. **Document**: Note resolution for records

## Best Practices

- Resolve conflicts promptly
- Communicate with sales on major changes
- Document resolution reasons
- Learn from conflicts to prevent future ones
- Use system tools for detection

## Related Concepts

- See "Inventory Management" for availability information
- See "Spot Statuses and Lifecycle" for spot tracking

concepts.title: Preemption
concepts.description: Understanding when and why spots get preempted
concepts.content:
# Preemption

## What is Preemption?

Preemption occurs when a scheduled commercial is replaced by other content before it can air. The scheduled spot is "bumped" to make room for something else.

## Why Preemption Happens

### Breaking News

- Major news events require immediate coverage
- Scheduled commercials replaced with news
- Cannot be avoided
- Public interest priority

### Special Programming

- Special events or shows
- Live coverage of events
- Station specials
- Higher priority content

### Higher Priority Orders

- Premium advertisers with priority
- Political ads (during windows)
- Station commitments
- Contractual obligations

### Technical Issues

- Equipment problems
- Missing copy (temporary)
- Playback errors
- System failures

## How Preempted Spots Are Handled

### Automatic Detection

- System detects spot didn't air
- Marks spot as MISSED
- Records preemption reason
- Notifies traffic manager

### Makegood Process

1. **Identify**: Spot marked as preempted
2. **Create Makegood**: Traffic manager creates replacement
3. **Schedule**: New spot scheduled (free to advertiser)
4. **Track**: Makegood tracked for fulfillment
5. **Invoice**: Appears on invoice at $0

### Comparable Placement

Makegoods should be:
- Similar daypart/time
- Same length
- Comparable audience
- Scheduled promptly

## Preemption vs Other Issues

### Preemption vs Technical Failure

- **Preemption**: Replaced by other content
- **Technical Failure**: Equipment problem, nothing aired
- Both result in makegoods
- Different reasons

### Preemption vs Cancellation

- **Preemption**: Unplanned, requires makegood
- **Cancellation**: Planned, no makegood needed
- Preemption is reactive
- Cancellation is proactive

## Special Cases

### Political Ads

- **Cannot be preempted** (usually)
- Protected during political windows
- Highest priority
- Exception: Only if legally required

### Premium Advertisers

- May have no-preemption clauses
- Contractual protection
- Higher rates for protection
- Station commitment

## Communication

### With Advertisers

- Notify if significant preemption
- Explain reason
- Assure makegood will be scheduled
- Maintain relationship

### Internal Communication

- Traffic manager coordinates
- Log generator aware
- Sales notified if needed
- Document all preemptions

## Best Practices

- Minimize preemptions when possible
- Create makegoods promptly
- Ensure comparable placement
- Communicate with advertisers
- Document all preemptions
- Track preemption reasons
- Review patterns to prevent

## Related Concepts

- See "Makegoods" for makegood details
- See "Spot Statuses and Lifecycle" for status information
- See "Political Advertising and FCC Compliance" for political ad rules

concepts.title: Live Reads vs Pre-Produced Spots
concepts.description: Understanding the differences between live reads and pre-produced commercials
concepts.content:
# Live Reads vs Pre-Produced Spots

## Overview

There are two main types of radio commercials: **Live Reads** (DJ reads a script) and **Pre-Produced** (recorded audio file). Each has advantages and is suited for different situations.

## Pre-Produced Spots

### What They Are

- Recorded commercial audio file
- Uploaded to system
- Plays automatically
- Same every time

### Advantages

- **Consistency**: Exact same message every time
- **Quality**: Professional production
- **No Talent Needed**: Plays automatically
- **Reliable**: No human error in delivery
- **Flexible**: Can be used anytime

### Disadvantages

- **Less Personal**: Sounds like typical ad
- **Production Cost**: Must be produced
- **Less Flexible**: Can't adapt to moment
- **Generic**: May sound like other ads

### Best For

- National or large advertisers
- Complex products needing explanation
- When consistency is critical
- High production value needed
- Standard messaging

## Live Reads

### What They Are

- Script provided to DJ/host
- Read on-air during live programming
- More conversational
- Can adapt to moment

### Advantages

- **Personal**: DJ's voice, more authentic
- **Local Connection**: Feels like recommendation
- **Flexibility**: Can adapt to programming
- **Trust**: Listeners trust DJ's voice
- **Engagement**: More engaging delivery

### Disadvantages

- **Inconsistency**: May vary each time
- **Coordination**: Requires talent coordination
- **Timing**: Must be scheduled for live reads
- **Risk**: Human error possible
- **Limited Availability**: Only during live shows

### Best For

- Local businesses
- When personal touch matters
- Quick promotions
- When DJ endorsement helps
- Flexible messaging

## Key Differences

### Delivery

- **Pre-Produced**: Automated playback
- **Live Read**: DJ reads script

### Consistency

- **Pre-Produced**: Same every time
- **Live Read**: May vary slightly

### Cost

- **Pre-Produced**: Production cost upfront
- **Live Read**: May have talent fee

### Timing

- **Pre-Produced**: Can air anytime
- **Live Read**: Only during live shows

### Personalization

- **Pre-Produced**: Generic
- **Live Read**: Personal, authentic

## Pricing Differences

### Pre-Produced

- Standard commercial rates
- Based on time and placement
- No additional talent fees

### Live Reads

- May have premium rate
- Talent coordination fee possible
- Higher cost for personal touch

## Choosing Between Them

### Choose Pre-Produced If

- Need consistency
- Complex product explanation
- National advertiser
- Professional production important
- Flexible scheduling needed

### Choose Live Read If

- Local business
- Personal recommendation helps
- Quick, flexible messaging
- DJ endorsement valuable
- Authenticity important

## Coordination Requirements

### Pre-Produced

- Upload audio file
- Assign to order
- System plays automatically
- Minimal coordination

### Live Reads

- Provide script to DJ
- Schedule for live show times
- Coordinate with talent
- May need reminders
- Verify delivery

## Best Practices

### For Pre-Produced

- Upload early
- Verify audio quality
- Test playback
- Set expiration dates

### For Live Reads

- Provide clear scripts
- Include pronunciation guides
- Schedule appropriately
- Follow up on delivery
- Thank talent

## Related Concepts

- See "Copy Management" for managing both types
- See "Voice Tracking" for recorded voice elements

concepts.title: Audio Library Management
concepts.description: Understanding how music and audio assets are stored and used
concepts.content:
# Audio Library Management

## What is the Audio Library?

The audio library is where all music tracks, sound effects, station IDs, and other audio assets are stored. It's the "music collection" that gets used when generating daily logs.

## Why Audio Library Matters

- **Log Generation**: System selects music from library
- **Consistency**: Same library used across logs
- **Organization**: Easy to find and use audio
- **Quality**: Ensures broadcast-quality audio
- **Licensing**: Tracks legal use of music

## Types of Audio in Library

### Music Tracks

- Songs for music programming
- Organized by genre, artist, etc.
- Used to fill music slots in logs
- Rotated to avoid repetition

### Station IDs

- Legal station identification
- Frequency and call letters
- Required by FCC
- Played at top of hour

### Sound Effects

- Bumpers, stings, beds
- Transitions between content
- Station branding elements
- Production elements

### Voice Tracks

- Pre-recorded DJ breaks
- Liners and promos
- Station announcements
- Used in voice tracking

## Audio Quality Requirements

### Broadcast Quality

- High-quality audio files
- Proper bitrate and sample rate
- No distortion or noise
- Professional production

### File Formats

- MP3, WAV, or other formats
- Consistent format preferred
- Proper encoding
- System-compatible

## Library Organization

### By Category

- Genre (Rock, Country, etc.)
- Type (Music, ID, Effect)
- Source (Library, Production)
- Usage (Regular, Special)

### Metadata

- Artist name
- Song title
- Duration
- Genre
- BPM (beats per minute)
- Date added

## How Audio is Selected for Logs

### Automatic Selection

- System selects from library
- Based on clock template
- Rotates to avoid repetition
- Matches programming format

### Selection Rules

- Genre matching
- Rotation rules
- Time of day appropriateness
- Avoid recent plays

## Library Management Tasks

### Adding Audio

1. Upload audio file
2. Enter metadata
3. Categorize
4. Set usage rules
5. Verify quality

### Organizing Library

- Keep categories current
- Remove outdated tracks
- Update metadata
- Archive old content

### Quality Control

- Verify audio quality
- Check for errors
- Test playback
- Remove problematic files

## Best Practices

- Maintain organized library
- Keep metadata accurate
- Regular quality checks
- Archive old content
- License compliance
- Regular updates

## Related Concepts

- See "Clock Templates" for how audio fits in programming
- See "Voice Tracking" for voice elements

concepts.title: Log Revisions
concepts.description: Understanding how to fix mistakes after logs are published
concepts.content:
# Log Revisions

## What are Log Revisions?

Log revisions are updated versions of published logs. When a mistake is found after a log is published, you create a revision to fix it without losing the original.

## When Revisions Are Needed

### Mistakes Found

- Wrong spot scheduled
- Incorrect timing
- Missing content
- Wrong music selected

### Last-Minute Changes

- Advertiser requests change
- Breaking news requires update
- Technical issues discovered
- Programming adjustments needed

### After Publishing

- Log already published to LibreTime
- Cannot edit published log directly
- Must create revision
- Revision replaces original

## Creating Log Revisions

### Process

1. **Identify Issue**: Find mistake in published log
2. **Create Revision**: System creates new version
3. **Make Changes**: Edit revision with corrections
4. **Review**: Verify all fixes are correct
5. **Publish Revision**: Replace original with revision

### What Gets Revised

- Spot placements
- Timing adjustments
- Music selections
- Content changes
- Any log elements

## Revision vs Original

### Original Log

- First version published
- Kept for records
- Shows what was originally planned
- Historical record

### Revision

- Updated version
- Replaces original for playback
- Contains corrections
- Linked to original

## When to Create Revisions

### Immediately

- Critical errors found
- Must fix before airtime
- Affects contract fulfillment

### As Needed

- Non-critical fixes
- Can wait until convenient
- Minor adjustments

## Best Practices

- Review logs before publishing
- Catch errors early
- Create revisions promptly when needed
- Document reason for revision
- Verify revisions are correct
- Communicate changes to team

## Related Concepts

- See "Log Generator Workflow" for log creation
- See "Spot Statuses and Lifecycle" for spot tracking

concepts.title: Playback History
concepts.description: Understanding how the system tracks what actually aired
concepts.content:
# Playback History

## What is Playback History?

Playback history is a record of what actually played on-air, as confirmed by the automation system (LibreTime). It shows the difference between what was scheduled and what actually aired.

## Why Playback History Matters

### Billing Accuracy

- Invoice only what actually aired
- Verify scheduled vs actual
- Ensure accurate billing
- Prevent billing errors

### Contract Fulfillment

- Track if spots actually aired
- Identify missed spots
- Verify makegoods aired
- Confirm contract completion

### Troubleshooting

- See what actually happened
- Identify playback issues
- Debug scheduling problems
- Verify system accuracy

## Playback History vs Scheduled

### Scheduled Spots

- What was planned to air
- From daily logs
- May not match actual
- Planning document

### Playback History

- What actually aired
- From automation system
- Real playback record
- Actual events

### Differences

- Scheduled: Planned time
- Playback: Actual time (may vary slightly)
- Scheduled: What should air
- Playback: What did air

## How Playback History Works

### Automatic Tracking

- Automation system records playback
- System updates spot status
- Records actual air times
- Tracks what played

### Data Captured

- Actual air time
- What content played
- Duration
- Any issues or errors

## Using Playback Data

### For Billing

- Generate invoices from playback
- Only bill what aired
- Verify against scheduled
- Ensure accuracy

### For Makegoods

- Identify spots that didn't air
- Create makegoods for missed
- Track makegood fulfillment
- Verify replacement aired

### For Reporting

- Actual vs scheduled reports
- Playback accuracy metrics
- System performance
- Contract fulfillment rates

## Best Practices

- Review playback history regularly
- Compare scheduled vs actual
- Investigate discrepancies
- Use for accurate billing
- Track for reporting

## Related Concepts

- See "Spot Statuses and Lifecycle" for status information
- See "Makegoods" for handling missed spots
- See "Invoice Lifecycle" for billing process

concepts.title: Digital Orders (Future)
concepts.description: Understanding digital advertising orders for multi-platform campaigns
concepts.content:
# Digital Orders (Future Feature)

## Overview

Digital orders extend advertising beyond traditional radio to include digital platforms like websites, podcasts, streaming, and social media. This allows stations to offer comprehensive multi-platform advertising packages.

## What are Digital Orders?

Digital orders are advertising contracts for non-radio platforms:
- **Website**: Banner ads, display ads
- **Podcast**: Podcast advertising
- **Streaming**: Online streaming ads
- **Social Media**: Social platform advertising

## How Digital Orders Differ from Radio Orders

### Platform

- **Radio Orders**: Traditional broadcast
- **Digital Orders**: Online/digital platforms

### Pricing Models

- **Radio**: Per spot, fixed rates
- **Digital**: CPM (cost per thousand), CPC (cost per click), flat rate

### Measurement

- **Radio**: Spots aired
- **Digital**: Impressions, clicks, views

### Creative Assets

- **Radio**: Audio files
- **Digital**: Images, videos, HTML, etc.

## Digital Order Types

### Website Advertising

- Banner ads
- Display advertising
- Sponsored content
- Website integration

### Podcast Advertising

- Pre-roll, mid-roll, post-roll
- Host-read ads
- Dynamic insertion
- Podcast-specific creative

### Streaming Advertising

- Audio streaming ads
- Video streaming ads
- Platform-specific formats
- Streaming service integration

### Social Media Advertising

- Platform ads (Facebook, Instagram, etc.)
- Sponsored posts
- Social media creative
- Platform-specific requirements

## Pricing Models

### CPM (Cost Per Thousand)

- Pay per 1,000 impressions
- Common for display ads
- Based on views

### CPC (Cost Per Click)

- Pay per click
- Common for search/social
- Performance-based

### Flat Rate

- Fixed price
- Similar to radio spots
- Guaranteed placement

## When Digital Orders Are Used

### Multi-Platform Campaigns

- Advertiser wants radio + digital
- Comprehensive reach
- Integrated campaign

### Digital-Only

- Advertiser only wants digital
- No radio component
- Digital-focused campaign

### Supplement to Radio

- Radio campaign with digital boost
- Extended reach
- Additional touchpoints

## Creative Requirements

### Different Assets Needed

- **Radio**: Audio file
- **Digital**: Images, videos, HTML
- Platform-specific formats
- Multiple versions for different platforms

### Production Considerations

- Digital creative production
- Platform specifications
- Multiple format requirements
- Quality standards

## Integration with Radio Orders

### Combined Campaigns

- Radio + digital package
- Unified reporting
- Coordinated messaging
- Cross-platform tracking

## Status

**Note**: Digital orders are a planned future feature. The system structure exists, but full implementation may be in development.

## Related Concepts

- See "Orders vs Spots vs Logs" for radio order basics
- See "Campaign Management" for multi-platform campaigns
